Award.AwardTitle: Hopf algebras, Frobenius-Schur indicators and modular categories
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal investigator proposes to study Hopf algebras, modular tensor categories, and some of their invariants called Frobenius-Schur indicators. In particular, the following topics will be studied. (1) Classification of Hopf algebras of small dimension: It is fundamentally important to understand some basic examples in any mathematical theory. The PI will continue to work on the classification of Hopf algebras whose dimension admits a simple factorization.(2) Gauge invariants of finite-dimensional Hopf algebras: It is generally difficult to decide whether two given finite-dimensional Hopf algebras have monoidally inequivalent representation categories. The PI expects to discover some invariants under Drinfeld twists, which are generalizations of Frobenius-Schur indicators to arbitrary finite-dimensional Hopf algebras. (3) Arithmetic properties of Frobenius-Schur indicators: The arithmetic properties of Frobenius-Schur indicators have led to the quantum Cauchy theorem for integral fusion categories and a congruence subgroup theorem for modular tensor categories. The PI will continue to explore these properties and their applications to fusion categories.

The appeal of symmetry has been guidance for understanding the nature of science. Some symmetry can be described in terms of algebraic structures. For instance, the symmetry of platonic solids can be described by some finite groups of spatial rotations. The symmetry of some physical systems can be described by Hopf algebras, and tensor categories, which are closely related to other areas of mathematics such as representation theory, topological invariants, and conformal field theory. The proposed research studies some fundamental questions in the field, with an eye on applications in other areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hopf algebras and spherical fusion categories are generalizations of finite groups, which are commonly used to describe symmetry in nature. For instance, the symmetry of platonic solids can be described by certain finite groups of spatial rotations. Hopf algebras and tensor categories have been adopted to describe the symmetry of some physical systems, and they are closely related to many areas of mathematics and physics. This research project studied some fundamental questions in Hopf algebras and spherical fusion categories.  

 

A basic invariant of a Hopf algebra is its dimension that is a positive integer defined by the Hopf algebra. One of the objectives of this project is to classify Hopf algebras of small dimension. It has been proved that there are infinitely non-isomorphic Hopf algebras of dimension 32. Before the completion of this project, all dimensions less than 32 except 20, 24 and 28 were classified, and they all have finitely many isomorphism classes. One of the contributions of this project is the complete classification of Hopf algebras of dimensions 20, 28 and 44, and they also have only finitely many isomorphism classes.

Besides dimension, the other numerical invariants, called Frobenius-Schur indicators, can also be defined for each Hopf algebra or spherical fusion category. These numbers are not integers but they satisfy some monic integral polynomials with abelian Galois groups. One of the outcomes of this project is the discovery that each sequence of Frobenius-Schur indicators satisfies a certain linearly recursive relation. Moreover, the monic polynomial, which describes the linearly recursive relation of a sequence of Frobenius-Schur indicators, is also an invariant of the Hopf algebra or spherical fusion category.

The arithmetic properties of these Frobenius-Schur indicators obtained in this project are of fundamental importance. Although an individual Frobenius-Schur indicator is a complex number, certain sums of these indicators, called the total indicators, of a semisimple Hopf algebra are always positive integers. These total indicators are not the same as the dimension of the Hopf algebra and they can provide a sufficient condition to distinguish quasi-Hopf algebras from genuine Hopf algebras up to gauge equivalence. 

The generalized Frobenius-Schur indicators defined for spherical fusion categories admit even more arithmetic properties. One of the most significant discoveries of the project is that the modular group of 2x2 integer matrices of determinant 1, and the absolute Galois group over rational numbers both act as symmetry group on the generalized Frobenius-Schur indicators in a compatible manner.  Therefore, the arithmetic properties of these indicators are also revealed in the modular group. This discovery has many applications in the other areas of mathematics. These applications, which include the proofs of several conjectures in conformal field theory, are important outcomes of this project.
